HEADLINE: In Chicago's West Loop, Real Estate Profits Do Grow on Trees

BYLINE: By LISA CHAMBERLAIN

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
WHEN Mayor Richard M. Daley began a tree-planting campaign after winning his first election in 1989, many people here snickered. The mayor of Chicago -- a brass-knuckles town if there ever was one -- is a tree-hugger?
 But the snickers have slowly turned into a growing chorus of cheers as tree plantings, elaborate landscaping and streetscape designs have become the catalyst for neighborhood revitalization. 
 One urban area targeted by Mayor Daley wasn't even really a neighborhood, but it is today, and a hot one at that. The West Loop, just west of Chicago's famous Loop, was one of the first areas outside of the immediate downtown area to receive the mayor's landscaping treatment. The once-flourishing industrial area had become rather seedy. Empty warehouses and litter-strewn lots dominated vast tracts of land. A few pioneering artists moved in, and then not much happened. But that all changed when Mayor Daley directed his staff to spruce up the landscape dramatically. 
 One of the streets, Randolph, was turned into a Parisian-style boulevard. Two median strips were built and landscaped with trees, flowers and shrubs, creating a central artery for traffic and curb lanes for accessing local businesses. Streetscaping came next, with new lighting, sidewalk planters and public art. Not long after that, some of the best restaurants in town sprang up in what had been windowless, metal-gated buildings. Loft conversions began in earnest, with new construction coming later.
 In 1998, Yuval Degani, who had been living in a 1,500-square-foot loft above a meatpacking company where the rent was $575 a month, bought a six-unit building that dates back to the 1890's for $363,000. Over the years, he spent about $275,000 on the building and converted three units into one ultramodern 3,500-square-foot, three-floor, six-bedroom condo for himself and his wife, who at the time was an anesthesiology resident at the University of Illinois at Chicago. 
 ''When I bought this building,'' he said, ''there was a sign out front that said, 'No Cruising.' I'm from Israel, so I didn't know what that meant. I had to ask.'' Cruising, of course, was a euphemism for prostitution, and according to Mr. Degani, the sign wasn't much of a deterrent. 
 In the course of looking for this property, Mr. Degani got a real estate license to handle the transaction himself. Next thing he knew, he was handling real estate deals in the neighborhood for friends, which ultimately led to Dream Town Realty, a residential brokerage and development firm he started with a partner. They initially specialized in the West Loop, but now have business all over the city. Mr. Degani expects to sell his West Loop building in the near future, and will ask about $1.2 million.
 ''Development here probably would have happened eventually,'' Mr. Degani said. ''But the city's investment was a huge signal to the community.''
 In 1996, when Randolph Street was under construction, there were 76 residential units sold in the entire West Loop, a large geographic area. Total volume was just over $14 million, with an average selling price of $187,662. By 2003, 960 residential units were sold, averaging $306,043 each, for a total volume just shy of $300 million, according to Dream Town. In 2004, the average price has so far climbed to $327,995.
 ''This used to be a desolate street,'' said Janet Attarian, project director of the city's Streetscape and Urban Design program, while giving a tour of Randolph. ''The mayor really believes that the physical environment has a big impact on economics, the culture and perception of the city.'' 
 Ms. Attarian said that it had been an evolving process, and that some of the earliest projects would not be repeated today. For instance, Madison, another West Loop street, had one of the very first medians. But it was far too narrow to have much of an impact on the character of the street and is difficult to maintain. 
 The city also had to learn the hard way about plants and trees that can sustain themselves through harsh Chicago winters while being pelted with rock salt. 
 Under Mayor Daley, the city of Chicago has built and landscaped 70 miles of medians, refurbished 80 miles of streetscapes and planted more than 400,000 trees. While only a fraction of the budget, these green initiatives have paid dividends for the city.
 ''I think Mayor Daley is appreciated for taking the city -- which was extremely utilitarian looking when I moved here in the late 1970's -- and spreading this aesthetic sensibility throughout the neighborhoods,'' said Larry Bennett, a political science professor at DePaul University, who specializes in redevelopment issues.
 Chris Beukenkamp and Rebecca Coke recently married and bought a place in the West Loop. Ms. Coke had rented an apartment in the West Loop before she and Mr. Beukenkamp found a house in a newer development constructed around the skeleton of a parking garage that had served the old Chicago Daily News building (which was converted to condos).
 In an urban interpretation of the cul-de-sac, the houses line both sides of a walkway that dead-ends into the building. The old parking garage beams connect the free-standing houses, soaring overhead between the homes and over the landscaped central walkway, which leads to the street.
 The couple fell in love with one of the 2,400-square-foot, four-story houses -- with its 18-foot ceilings, interesting angles and rooftop deck -- which they bought in December for $390,000. The first-floor entrance leads to the house's guest space, with the kitchen and dining area on the second floor, living area and bedroom on the third floor, and an office and rooftop access on the fourth floor. They liked it much better than the other places they saw, which all had the same floor plan. ''You could close your eyes, walk into a place and know exactly where everything is,'' Mr. Beukenkamp said. ''We wanted to be here. The best restaurants are within walking distance. There are three parks nearby. There's even a Starbucks now.''
 Ms. Coke said she likes the changes in the West Loop, as do her friends. ''I think our generation has the right mentality for living in the city,'' Ms. Coke said. ''We grew up in the suburbs and want something else. I want to make a commitment to stay even after we have a family.''

HEADLINE: Digging Out Along the Delaware

BYLINE: By JEREMY PEARCE and JESSICA BRUDER

DATELINE: HARMONY TOWNSHIP 

 BODY:
ON rainy days, as residents along the swollen Delaware River have come to see, the flotsam of life consists of sodden luggage, wrecked bicycles, logs, liberated lawn chairs, propane tanks, porches and other bits of backyard debris.
 But when the Delaware flooded two weeks ago -- fed by the last gasps of Hurricane Ivan to become the river's most destructive flood in eight years and a disaster comparable to its historic flooding in 1955 -- it washed in other and more surprising arrivals.
 Portable toilets popped up across the landscape on both the New Jersey and Pennsylvania sides, the result of swamped municipal sewage systems unable to handle the surge. River waters crested at more than 23 feet in Trenton, poured into the State House and closed state offices. To the north, the cascade passing through Phillipsburg was the third-highest measured in the past 100 years and carried a house beneath the Phillipsburg-Easton bridges. Damages to buildings and roads on both states' banks was extensive, leading to pleas for immediate federal disaster relief. 
 Even so, most surprising has been the reaction -- or lack of it -- by federal officials.
 Only a day into the flooding, on Sept. 19, Pennsylvania was granted aid by the Federal Emergency Management Agency to help in the recovery of 46 of its counties, spanning from the Delaware to the state's western edges, which suffered an estimated $180 million in property damage. Accordingly, on Sept. 20, Governor McGreevey also appealed to the federal agency to provide relief for four counties in New Jersey -- Mercer, Warren, Sussex and Hunterdon -- and last week was still waiting for a reply. Total damages in New Jersey have reached $33 million, according to an assessment by the state Office of Emergency Management.
 ''It's very infuriating and distressing down here,'' said Bonnie-Marie A. Dakis, the deputy municipal clerk for Harmony Township, in Warren County, a town where waters deluged 148 houses and residents were still mopping up in recent days.
 Continuing rain falling throughout the week did not help matters. Ruined mattresses, furniture and other items sat in piles before the houses on Goat Farm Road, where someone had posted a sign, ''We don't need sightseers, we need workers.''
 ''It is not a time for politics or games,'' said Ms. Dakis, giving voice to the accusation of political preferences in play for Pennsylvania, considered a crucial swing state in the presidential election next month, heard along the river. ''These people on this side are in the same predicament.''
 For some residents and state officials, mostly Democrats, the assumption has been that the Bush administration is turning a cold shoulder to New Jersey's disaster petition because the heavily Democratic state -- recent polls notwithstanding -- is expected to go for John Kerry.
 But Lea Anne McBride, a spokeswoman for the emergency management agency in Washington, said the state's request was ''in process'' and had not necessarily been denied. With the descent of Hurricane Jeanne on Florida last week, the agency has been particularly hard-pressed with disaster petitions, Ms. McBride added. Last week, the Bush administration proposed an additional $7.1 billion to rebuild Florida -- also considered a key state in the election -- on top of earlier aid requests for slightly more than $5 billion.
 ''We have to do our preliminary damage assessment for New Jersey,'' said Ms. McBride. ''We are working through the request and we certainly try to turn these around.''
 Yet others still interpret partisan motivations behind the delay.
 ''Why does this not surprise me?'' asked State Senator Shirley K. Turner, a Democrat of Mercer County, whose constituency includes Trenton and Ewing Township, two places where floodwaters caused some residents to evacuate their houses.
 ''It is the political season,'' said Ms. Turner, nearly coining a slogan with her words ''Pennsylvania is a battleground state. We haven't gotten satisfaction and I guess New Jersey will have to wait.'' 
 Assemblyman W. Reed Gusciora, a Democrat of Trenton, pushed the point even further, likening the lack of disaster aid to the apportionment of Homeland Security money. Mr. Gusciora said that New Jersey had ranked ''eighth or ninth'' in the nation for the amount of federal dollars it receives for homeland security, even with its proximity to the terrorist target of New York City.
 ''If the Bush administration will play with Homeland Security aid,'' he said, ''then it's likely they'll play with who gets the disaster aid.''
 The state's two Democratic senators Jon S. Corzine and Frank R. Lautenberg, have written to President Bush requesting federal aid to help pay for the flood. Governor McGreevey declared a state of emergency and sent his own letter to Mr. Bush, asking for ''disaster unemployment assistance, crisis counseling, public assistance, hazard mitigation and Small Business Administration disaster loans'' to resuscitate the four riverside counties.
 Yet the governor stopped short of mentioning political motivations. Juliet Johnson, a spokeswoman for Mr. McGreevey, had only this to say about the situation: ''As of now, FEMA has not responded. Certainly, the governor is disappointed. There are families out there struggling to get back on their feet.'' 
 In the flooded counties, Republicans have resisted the notion of partisanship, and suggested that the McGreevey administration's tardiness in recognizing the disaster and applying to federal officials were possible reasons for the emergency agency's delayed response.
 Asked if questions of national politics were blocking relief, state Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican of Hunterdon County, said: ''I hope not. There should be absolutely no partisanship about this issue.'' 
 Then, noting that rural Sussex, Warren and Hunterdon counties tend to be known as Republican strongholds in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, Mr. Lance added, ''We expect the federal government to grant our request as quickly as possible.''
 Another Republican, Assemblyman Guy R. Gregg of Flanders, in Sussex County, blamed Mr. McGreevey for being ''somewhat slow on the uptake'' in reporting the urgency of the flood.
 ''I was told,'' said Mr. Gregg, ''that, as a state, we were not as expeditious as Pennsylvania in our application. But it's not a question of what the decision will be -- FEMA will respond. It does appear that New Jersey could have gotten a faster dollar.''
 And Assemblywoman Allison Littell McHose, a Republican of Sparta, also in Sussex County, said the federal response had been appropriate and that ''when you measure the damages, Pennsylvania got harder hit and had more more damages.''
 Ms. McHose concluded: ''I don't see a political aspect to this situation.''
 Nor did the rising waters of the Delaware. In New Jersey, the flood damaged 844 houses and 47 apartments, for an estimated loss of $18.7 million, according to the state's figures. Damages to roads were estimated to be about $7.5 million, in addition to effects on utilities, parks and public buildings. No lives were reported lost on either side of the river.
 Warren County sustained the most widespread destruction of property and farm crops. Sussex County, where the Delaware's riverbanks are for the most part lightly populated, reported the least. And yet, in Hunterdon County, the downtown section of Lambertville was awash in floodwaters, as was New Hope, Pa., right across the river. Both towns are enclaves for restaurants, shops and art galleries, some of which were still closed last week after the waters receded.
 In Phillipsburg, situated near the point where Interstate 78 crosses the Delaware, the river shut down a sewage pumping station for two days and caused $100,000 in damages to a youth recreation building, said Mayor Harry L. Wyant. But for the most part Phillipsburg was protected by several steep stone bluffs on which the town was built.
 ''We were somewhat spared,'' acknowledged Mr. Wyant. ''But below and above us, the towns were not as fortunate. We see all the criteria in place for federal aid.''
 To the north in Belvidere, another significant river town, the Delaware's rising was joined by the flooding of the Pequest River, which runs through the town to join the larger river. Mayor Charles J. Liegel, Sr., said that 10 houses were badly damaged, adding that about 20 other houses had flooded basements and that the effects were more dire than the disaster of 1996, when ice floes holding back the flow of the Delaware River caused another memorable flood.
 ''We have big-rig trouble out here,'' said Mr. Wyant, before pausing. ''I'm trying to get my people the help they deserve, and FEMA says they can't do anything without a decree from above. I'd hate to think that politics is deciding this.''
 Nearby Belvidere, the river also overran parts of Knowlton and White Township. But at no point along the 100 miles or so of flooding were conditions more desperate than in Harmony Township, where last week there was a marked discord among the more than 140 houses drying out.
 Inner spoils of the houses were jumbled in piles by the roadsides, as residents living next to the river reported near-total losses. Ms. Dakis, the town's deputy clerk, and others are seeking federal aid to help pay for temporary housing as well as low-interest loans to begin repairs, although some residents also have private flood insurance. Fire trucks from the local department traveled from house to house to pump out silt-filled basements.
 On River Edge Lane, the houses were being gutted of their walls and insulation and the trees still carried the flood's high-water mark. Most dwellings bore symbols spray-painted on exterior walls -- the sign that state police had navigated the street by boat and checked for stranded survivors. Ms. Dakis noted that 450 people in Harmony were displaced by the storm.
 At the home of Nadine Shandor, a mental-health counselor, the waters stood at six feet in the living room. Ms. Shandor's back deck floated away and now leans against the house next door. She intends to move her house farther away from the riverbank. 
 ''My propane tank ended up in Burlington County,'' she said, before declaring, ''We're staying. The flood made everyone's resolve that much stronger.''
 Along Harmony's Goat Farm Road, the devastation was also in view. Stephanie Wydner, a retired teacher, was piling up furniture that she said had been handed down in her family. In the aftermath of the flood, Ms. Wydner discovered fish swimming in the basement. The river's waters even carried away a steel plate covering the valve of her drinking well.
 '' ''This was the first time in my life that I've seen all of these men, tough and strong guys, cry,'' she said.
 Solutions for taming the Delaware's flooding have seemed about as frustrating. A federal proposal to dam the upper reaches of the river -- the so-called Tocks Island project -- was dropped in the early 1990's, after environmentalists pointed out that it would corrupt Philadelphia's supply of drinking water. While the project was intended to control the river, it would probably have allowed salt water from Delaware Bay to advance upriver, fouling the city's water intakes. As it now flows, the Delaware's main stem runs unfettered and without dams for 330 miles, from Hancock, N.Y., dividing and defining New Jersey and Pennsylvania before rolling into the sea.
 One environmentalist, Jeff Tittel, director of the Sierra Club of New Jersey, has advocated a more complex approach to lessening flood damages. While acknowledging the difficulties, Mr. Tittek argues for moving houses and buildings back from the river, removing outdated dams on tributaries and pursuing open-space policies statewide. Open spaces and wetlands, he reasons, are areas that allow rainwater to percolate down into the soil, rather than to rapidly run off and raise a swelling river.
 ''Even now, we're still building in floodplains,'' said Mr. Tittel, who observed the recent flood from a lawn chair at his house in Lambertville. ''Even now, we're building parking lots on stream banks, creating things that make waters run off faster and do more damage.''
 Maya van Rossum, an environmental lawyer and the Delaware Riverkeeper -- a sort of personification of public efforts of preserve the purity of the river -- has taken Mr. Tittel's suggestions and run with them.
 ''Every time we have a flood like this one,'' said Ms. van Rossum, who is based in Washington Crossing, Pa., ''there's a lesson to be learned.'' 
 She is pushing for voluntary buyouts of private property along the Delaware and a permanent restoration of the river's basin, a notion seen by many homeowners and taxpayers as farfetched. Still, the Riverkeeper is not easily contained.
 ''After every flood event, we have to invest for people to rebuild,'' Ms. van Rossum explained. ''The public is literally buying the same houses many times over. That's an expensive undertaking in itself, when you are also paying to repair roads and bridges and supply emergency services.''
 She looked at it this way: ''All of the options are expensive. We want to move people out of harm's way and keep people out of harm in the future. Buying their property is the best way.''
 Given the regularity of flooding on the Delaware, the question remains as to why people continue to build so close to the river. Outside of Belvidere last week, Jeffrey Bugge methodically raked gravel and jetsam from the grounds around King Cole Grove, a restaurant and unofficial landmark on Route 46 that has been run by his family since the 1920's.
 The building sits on a bluff above the river, with views of rocks, greenery and small islands upstream and down. Mr. Bugge has lived through many spates, many floods, including the latest, which closed the restaurant for a week.
 ''It's a beautiful site,'' he said, returning to his raking. ''This is the price of being here.''

HEADLINE: Left High and Dry After the Flood

BYLINE: By JESSICA BRUDER

DATELINE: HARMONY TOWNSHIP 

 BODY:
WHEN Kyle Kels returned home to Hutchinson River Road two days after the floodwaters pushed him out, fish were swimming in his backyard. Water had crept six feet up the walls of his two-story stone cottage, and the entire first floor was still covered in a thick carpet of muck and silt the Delaware River left behind. 
 Like most of his neighbors, the 37-year-old Mr. Kels had evacuated the area with his family on the afternoon of Saturday, Sept. 18, after lugging everything he could carry -- clothing, photographs, small pieces of furniture -- to the second floor of his house. When he came back on Monday, his street looked like the victim of a child's tantrum. A dock had been flung up on someone's lawn. Five-hundred-gallon propane tanks with concrete anchors had sailed away like toy boats. A wooden picnic table was perched atop a gazebo. 
 Just two weeks ago, the remnants of Hurricane Ivan wrung out torrents of rain over the Northeast, causing the Delaware River to spill into parts of New Jersey and Pennsylvania. In New Jersey, the flood damage was spread across Warren, Hunterdon, Mercer and Sussex counties and totaled an estimated $33 million. 
 Though the Federal Emergency Management Agency declared a disaster area in parts of Pennsylvania a few days after the deluge, flood victims in New Jersey are still waiting to hear if the state's request for aid will be granted. In Harmony Township, situated 55 miles northwest of Trenton, most riverside residents were covered by flood insurance, but they still hope that supplementary aid from the federal government, which could include direct grants and low-interest loans, will help them get through temporary shortfalls and prepare for the future. 
 For Mr. Kels, a self-employed contractor, his wife, Janis Kels, 35, and their four young children, the emergency agency may be the only hope. The biggest shock of their homecoming was neither the fish in the backyard nor the filth on the floor. It came, rather, when the Kels called their flood insurance company to report the damage. 
 ''We called and they said that our policy expired,'' Ms. Kels said. ''I thought it was an error. We refinanced back in May, and the mortgage company screwed up somehow and canceled our flood insurance because they said it wasn't in the flood zone. They thought we were in Lopatcong.'' 
 Now, in addition to repairing more than $75,000 in damages to their home, the Kels must retain a lawyer. Add to that the expense of renting an apartment 10 minutes away, in Washington Township, where the Kels have been living, and the picture dims further. 
 Mr. Kels' coping strategy is based in construction. He has been working long hours with an army of friends and neighbors to gut his first floor and replace every inch of sheet rock and insulation. At night, he sleeps in a makeshift arrangement on the second floor -- his master bedroom on the first floor is now gone -- to discourage possible looters. If he toils fast enough, he hopes, he can go back to his paying job and have his family back home in a month. But he is not sure if they will be coming home to stay. 
 ''My husband has lived here all his life,'' Ms. Kels explained. ''We bought the house from his mom, so it would be hard to move.'' 
 Still, Mr. Kels is not sure whether he can afford to keep the house, which was passed down from his great-grandparents and has been flooded out twice in the past, in 1955 and 1996. Without the support of flood insurance or the emergency management agency, it is hard to imagine another shot at life along the unpredictable Delaware. 
 ''We keep asking every day, but it doesn't seem to come through,'' Ms. Kels said of the state's request for federal aid. ''It's our only hope right now.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Janis Kels sweeping a floor in her house in Harmony Township, which she had to evacuate, along with her family. (Photo by Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Too Much of a Good Thing?

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD 

 BODY:
ILENE HARRISON has had an uneasy feeling about the downtown shopping district. 
 A resident of this upscale village of 25,000 for 11 years, Ms. Harrison could not define the feeling, but it crystalized one recent day when she saw a sign in the window of the former Laura Ashley store on Ridgewood Avenue announcing the opening of another new bank. 
 ''Towns need banks, but I don't know why a town needs 10 or more banks,'' said Ms. Harrison. 
 For her, the banks represent the village's larger problem: how to create an attractive, viable downtown without going overboard. 
 The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation lists 16 banks in the village, but a drive around town suggests that the number is closer to 18, with at least two more set to open. It is a fact that would have delighted Willie Sutton but frustrates residents like Ms. Harrison. It has grown so severe that even the Ridgewood Chamber of Commerce has taken it upon itself to put an end to the financial sprawl. 
 On Wednesday the Chamber of Commerce plans to propose that the Village Council amend the zoning ordinance to restrict not only the number of financial institutions in the downtown area, but also such village staples as beauty salons, nail salons, spas and even restaurants, which over the last 15 years have attracted people from all parts of North Jersey and made the village a prosperous culinary center. 
 Moribund commercial districts elsewhere would only be too happy for even a fraction of the banks, restaurants and beauty salons inundating Ridgewood. But Oliver Abel, the owner of Oliver's Chocolates and president of the Chamber of Commerce, who spearheaded the proposal, said that there can be too much of a good thing. 
 ''We're not trying to restrict competition,'' Mr. Abel said. ''We're trying to do two things: one is maintain some kind of parking for availability to shoppers, and secondly to maintain the proper mix of what a town like Ridgewood should be. We don't want Ridgewood to be known as just a restaurant and banking town.'' 
 There are 16 banks within the downtown shopping district. Four are within about four blocks of each other on East Ridgewood Avenue, the town's main street, with a fifth bank just one block across the railroad tracks on West Ridgewood Avenue. And at least two more are slated to open on East Ridgewood Avenue. The remainder can be found in close proximity to one another on side streets, including two side by side on Franklin Avenue, one block over from East Ridgewood Avenue.
 A Web search found some 15 beauty salons, nail salons and spas downtown. And, the Board of Health reports, there are 71 restaurants around the village, ranging from pizzerias and school cafeterias to elegant restaurants. 
 These businesses, Mr. Abel said, have created increased traffic congestion and exacerbated a shortage of parking spaces that the town has been unable to address. Plans for garages or lots have fallen through. A 2002 parking study showed a shortage of 1,298 spaces. 
 The three types of businesses together occupy 45 percent of the total street level square footage of all commercial buildings in the district, according to Mr. Abel. And because they employ more workers than most businesses in the village and attract more customers, they account for a disproportionate share of parking spaces. The proposed ordinance, he said, could be phased out when more parking becomes available. 
 James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, said that Ridgewood was not the only wealthy town experiencing such a quandary. Westfield and Princeton are among the others experiencing ''the downside of prosperity and affluence.''
 ''They are areas that are tremendously desirable, they have tremendously high incomes, and the end result is that the cost of land has really ratcheted up,'' Mr. Hughes said. ''As prices of land, went up, people were willing to bid up the rental levels even more to secure access, and what that did was push out very interesting and needed types of activities and services in downtown areas.''
 The result is that local businesses leave town, and chain stores and banks take their place, he said. ''Banks are deep-pocket activities, and they're willing to pay more rent.'' 
 As for the restaurants, there were a only handful in the late 1980's, and many stores were vacant. Councilman Patrick Mancuso recalls there being about a dozen when he became mayor in 1992. He credits Paul Callan, a councilman at the time, with the idea of allowing outdoor restaurants in town. 
 ''The economic situation wasn't that great,'' Mr. Mancuso said. ''We looked at it as a terrific opportunity. The worst we could do was fail.''
 During his next eight years a mayor and afterward, the number of restaurants grew exponentially. 
 The Chamber of Commerce is suggesting that the Council adopt either of two ordinances: one that would limit the total square footage devoted to restaurants, banks and personal services, or one that would require any of the three types of prospective business to obtain a zoning variance, which would involve a public hearing. 
 Mr. Mancuso said the timing is right to consider amending the zoning ordinance because the Council is in the process of updating the master plan. He did not indicate which way the Council was leaning on this issue but said the proposal would provide members a good chance to discuss the matter. 
 He said reaction to the proposal among chamber members, business owners, shopkeepers and residents, had been mostly positive. 
 The 15 members of the chamber's board voted unanimously to adopt the proposal, and 88 of the 100 chamber members who responded to a questionnaire voted to forward the proposal to the Council. 
 Even some bankers and restaurateurs are for it. Paul Vagianos, a Ridgewood resident and owner of It's Greek to Me, sees the proposed restrictions as a good ''stopgap'' measure until the town builds a parking garage or adds more parking lots. 
 ''If we don't have parking, prestige stores won't come to town,'' Mr. Vagianos said. ''They'll go to other towns where there's good parking.''
 When she read about the proposal, Ms. Harrison called the Chamber of Commerce to thank officials there for their concerns about downtown. ''I kind of thought I was the only one who thought this way,'' she said.
 She laments the recent loss of Drapkin's, a stationery and office supply store with a wide selection of greeting cards and magazines that anchored East Ridgewood Avenue near the railroad tracks for many years, and Sealfons Department Store and a number of little specialty shops that have closed over the years since she came to town, only to have been replaced by chains. 
 ''I really don't want to see the quaintness and small town feeling of Ridgewood disappear and the downtown become a mini-mall,'' she said.


GRAPHIC: Photos: Ridgewood Avenue in Ridgewood, N.J., top and left. Oliver Abel and Debra Kurzius, members of the Chamber of Commerce, are seeking to limit new stores.

HEADLINE: Elephants in the Neighborhood

BYLINE: By ARCHIE GOTTESMAN. 
Archie Gottesman lives in Summit, and will continue to display ''Kerry for President'' signs on her lawn.

 BODY:
BECAUSE of www.fundrace.org I can no longer pretend. 
 Before fundrace.org, it was easy to persuade myself that my neighbors and I shared the same political views. But when the truth stared at me from the computer screen, I had some re-examining to do. 
 ''Did you know that that there is a Web site where you can look up who gave money to Bush or Kerry and how much?'' 
 We were sitting around the dinner table, and my mother, who at 69 is a computer and political fiend, mentioned her find. 
 ''Is that legal?'' I asked.
 ''Sure,'' she said. ''Political contributions have always been public information. I'll send you the link.'' Since that night, I've become a political peeping Tom and, perhaps, a violator of suburban etiquette.
 First I looked up my husband, Gary, and myself for accuracy. So far, so good. We had both contributed to Wesley Clark's campaign when he still had one. My donation to John Kerry was also there. I was happy with my contributions but felt a little exposed; suddenly, my personal politics just seemed so public. I began to navigate the site. Searches are done by name and address and, basically, you can go up and down your street and see who gave how much to whom. This might sound like fun if you live in a town of politically like-minded people. I don't. We live in Summit: lovely, leafy, heavily Republican. I knew this before fundrace.com. I just didn't want to believe it. 
 I continued my search, and off came those rose-colored glasses. ''Oh no!'' I groaned.
 ''What?'' Gary asked. 
 ''Karen and Joe each gave $2,000 to Bush. So did those new people on the corner. And, oh my God, Jane and Bill, too.'' 
 (For the sake of neighborliness, I have changed the names of my friends and neighbors.)
 Gary, predictably, was unmoved. ''Why does any of that surprise you?'' 
 Why indeed? Did I think that these Republicans in this Republican town were really closet Democrats? Well, yes. For years I have persuaded myself that my friends and neighbors were only sort of Republicans -- the kind who voted that way when it didn't really matter. But now, with the stakes so high, they would certainly come to their senses and align themselves with the rest of our blue state. Fundrace.org forced me to face the truth. Unless, of course, my ''Republican'' friends are putting up Bush lawn signs and giving $2000 to Bush and still voting for Kerry. Even I don't believe that. 
 I calmed myself by scrolling through the site and was pleasantly surprised at some of the contributions made to the Kerry campaign. I found myself expressing love for a few neighbors whom I vowed to get to know better. When Summit got dull, I opened my address book and checked out people from other parts of my life. Dare I search for my first true love? We haven't spoken in over 10 years, but bad news. $750 to Bush. I knew that whole relationship had been a mistake. Like a weird stroll through my past, I discovered where my old friends ended up politically. 
 I checked a few more names and began to wonder how I could be such good friends with people whose politics are so different from mine. Am I a hypocrite? Should I be more selective about whom I socialize with? Maybe donations should be kept private. Or should I stop looking for reasons to put distance between us? We are, after all, more alike than we are different. Aside from the fact that I can't bear the sight of George Bush and my neighbor gave him $2,000, she and I are remarkably similar: same background, same economic level, same education. 
 I asked a few of my Republican friends what they saw in Bush. I phrased the question diplomatically -- ''I'm trying to keep an open mind and really want understand what will make you vote for George Bush in November?'' -- and vowed to keep my cool. One friend laughed and told me that we probably agree on more issues than we disagree on. She's right: abortion, equal rights, the environment, stem-cell research, capital punishment, financing for after-school programs, gun control; on all that we see eye to eye. But none of the domestic issues are enough to make her vote for Kerry. 
 I still like to fantasize that people I like are voting for Kerry. The other day I logged onto fundrace.org. My 8-year-old daughter, Sophie, came running down the stairs and asked if she could have a play date at Isabel's. ''Hmmm. Sure, Sophie, I'll call them. In a minute.'' 
 Let's see, Rita and Henry I couldn't help myself. I checked. Just what I thought: $500 each to Bush. Sophie looked at me impatiently. I wondered whether she was ready for a political lecture instead of a play date. 
 ''Sure,'' I sighed, ''I'll give Rita a call.'' 
 Later, I drove Sophie over to the Republican-donating home and had a perfectly lovely chat with Rita. I decided that Rita really gave that contribution to Bush because of her obviously Republican husband, Henry. She could pretend now, but Rita -- a smart woman -- would never actually vote for Bush. Come Nov. 2, she was going to get behind that curtain, where no Web site would ever tattle on her, and press the button for Kerry.

LENGTH: 1121 words

HEADLINE: Sailing On

BYLINE: By KELLY CROW

 BODY:
MORE than three decades ago, before the city had water taxis and the Hudson River Park, back when locals skirted New York Harbor, shimmery and sour as it was with oil slicks and condoms, there once bobbed a sailboat for hire. 
 This 70-foot yawl, called the Petrel, sailed into the city in 1972 and made her summer home by a floating dock just west of the Staten Island Ferry Terminal in Manhattan. Her skipper, a burly welder named Nick van Nes, spent the next 28 years sailing people around the harbor, a pioneer in the local charter business.
 It was into this scene that Thomas Berton, the son of East Village bohemians, skated on his Rollerblades one summer 15 years ago. Mr. van Nes was lugging a mainsail from his red pickup truck onto the Petrel, and Mr. Berton and a friend offered to help. As thanks, the skipper took them sailing. Within a week, Mr. Berton, then 24, was sleeping on the boat overnight as a volunteer member of the crew. 
 ''Typically, people were either turned off or they jumped to it,'' Mr. van Nes said recently. ''Tom jumped. But then, we weren't just a sailboat. We had a following, a little world.''
 Mr. Berton was only one of a giddy colony of urban sailors who came to cherish the Petrel and its weathered Peter Pan of a captain. Many, like Mr. Berton, knew nothing about sailing when they stumbled on the boat. Most were content to sail city waters, rarely venturing beyond. But more than a few grew up to helm and crew the Petrel, sometimes for pay but usually for the sport of it. Spending time on the boat became an urban ritual for these few dozen office workers, writers, brokers and social workers. So, all of them panicked when Mr. van Nes and the Petrel retired to Martha's Vineyard four years ago. 
 But this is a love story about two ships, not one. These city sailors have found a rescuer in one of their own, Mr. Berton, now 39. After prospering as a real estate and retail entrepreneur, he now owns a sailboat for hire. From early April through October, he takes people on sails costing $45 to $65 up to five times a day on his 82-foot, double-masted schooner, berthed at the North Cove Marina in Battery Park City. His sailboat is called the Shearwater, named for a seabird related to -- what else? -- the petrel.
 Mr. Berton said Mr. van Nes opened his and others' nautical eyes. ''Me, I was born and raised in New York,'' he said, ''so I could always answer the question of whether Manhattan was A) an island or B) an isthmus. But until we met Nick and the Petrel, we had no idea what it really meant to live on an island and love the water around it.''
 Just after sunset on a recent balmy Thursday, the Shearwater wriggled out of North Cove and into the Hudson. This maneuver requires the artless precision of a valet in a packed parking garage. At least 20 vessels of varying size and opulence sway in the marina. Of these, the Shearwater is almost certainly the oldest, built in 1929 as a gentleman's toy and operated mostly by hand and wind. But Matt Beck, one of its three alternating captains, steered with a quiet assurance. 
 Out in the water, Ellis Island glowed like a jack-o'-lantern. Canada geese skimmed over the waves, their silhouettes black in the mauve dusk. A dozen passengers watched from the teak decks. A few explored the mahogany staterooms below deck. A cluster, however, had gathered around Mr. Beck at the stern. These are the Petrel people, the regulars who knew Mr. Beck in the late 1980's when he was a still a screenwriter fresh from Rochester.
 THE bubbly woman smoking was Kathy Seng Gurland, 52, a social worker from the East Village who discovered the Petrel 14 years ago, and has volunteered to crew off and on ever since. (Some years, she took the Staten Island Ferry to and from her day job, only to run around the corner and board the Petrel for evening sails.) The crew gently teased her for two years until her hands were sufficiently calloused from rope burns to let her forgo gloves.
 Regulars still love to hear about how Mr. van Nes's parents taught their six children to sail on the family boat at City Island. They heard how his father bought the 1937 Petrel for $26,000 in a Coast Guard auction in early 1964. The boat had been a weekend plaything of President Kennedy's. They heard how her early crews in Battery Park were Mr. van Nes's welder friends from the Brooklyn Navy Yard. They heard about the 17-year old who went into labor during a sail in 1979, and gave her baby the same initials as Mr. van Nes's company, Bring Sailing Back. Over the years, these stories no longer belonged to one sailor. They blended into the group's shared mythology. 
 But more and more, Mr. van Nes let his captains oversee his boat while he stayed home, and even berthed the Petrel at Martha's Vineyard for the winter. He wearied of fighting, both for city permits and against competition. (At least three charter sailboats work from Lower Manhattan now.)
 Mr. Beck, tacking back toward the marina, said: ''I got my captain's license in 2000, and I called Nick to see when he was bringing the Petrel back. He said, 'I'm not,' and my heart just sank. Then he told me some guys were putting together another boat and I couldn't believe it. The Shearwater was my saving grace.'' 
 Mr. Berton spent $1 million buying the Shearwater and as much money on repairs after the ship was heavily damaged on Sept. 11. For a while, Petrel regulars were his only passengers. 
 A boyish but pensive host, he is more soft-spoken than Mr. van Nes. He has fewer tales of oceangoing seamanship and no salt-and-pepper beard. He feels more than anything like the resident adviser to this fraternity of Petrel fans. But they love him for that, too.
 Richard Balestrino, the executive editor for American Media Mini Mag Group, can once again take his favorite place along the bowsprit, which he calls the vessel's ''Titanic'' spot. His dog, Peaches, prefers the cockpit. Chris (Iron Man) van Nes, Mr. van Nes's nephew, can now play first mate to the Shearwater, having quit his job at an art-casting foundry upstate. Michael Fisher, the Northeast sales director for Texas Monthly magazine, can sit on deck at least twice a month and wish for wind. ''The more wind,'' Mr. Fisher said, ''the faster I'm there.'' 
 Now, it is Nick van Nes who turns wistful when friends call him with stories about the city. Most are about the Shearwater. And the new volunteers? Most are city kids like Noam Primak, 24, an economics major at Hunter College. Mr. Primak knows little about sailing and nothing about the Petrel. But he is smitten with the Shearwater. ''I haven't brought any friends out yet,'' he said, grinning on her deck in the twilight. ''I'm keeping this to myself for a while.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: OLD SALT -- Nick van Nes was master of the Petrel.
 NEW SALTS -- Nick van Nes's protege Tom Berton, below, and a nephew, Chris van Nes, left, now man the Shearwater. (Above, below and bottom, photographs by Michael Nagle for The New York Times)

COMPANY: PANASONIC APPLIANCES INDIA CO LTD (66%)

SECTION: Section 6; Column 3; Magazine Desk; THE NEXT CULTURAL ESTABLISHMENT; Pg. 76

LENGTH: 5203 words

HEADLINE: Where Have You Gone, Impresarios? E-76

BYLINE: By Jesse Green. 
Jesse Green is a frequent contributor to the magazine.

 BODY:
Joe Papp lay dying in a borrowed bed. The prostate cancer he had successfully beaten into remission (and tried to keep secret) since 1987 had, by the spring of 1991, returned with a vengeance. He could not go home. The modest apartment on Ninth Street in Greenwich Village that he shared with his fourth wife, Gail, had been turned into an infirmary for his son Tony, who at 28 was himself dying, of AIDS. At 69, Papp faced what would have seemed impossible throughout his years as the king of adventurous nonprofit American theater: an unwinnable fight. The man who had famously outmaneuvered Robert Moses in a struggle to build a Shakespeare playhouse in Central Park, who had saved the Astor Library on Lafayette Street from destruction and, with almost no money, turned it into the permanent base for his Public Theater, was, if not literally wandering a storm-swept heath, hopeless and in a way homeless. 
 A ''King Lear'' scenario, down to a loyal Kent: it was in Bernard Gersten's apartment that Papp found shelter as his world fell apart. Gersten had been Papp's closest associate -- his enabler, his good cop, his ''Japanese wife,'' a few steps behind and off to the side -- through most of the Public's battles and triumphs, from soon after its inception as the New York Shakespeare Festival in 1954 until 1978, when Papp suddenly, cruelly, almost capriciously fired him. Banished from the kingdom, Gersten went on to become executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater (a position he still holds), but in the end reconciled with his weakened old friend. Papp slept on and off for weeks in Gersten's bedroom (while Gersten and his wife commuted from Katonah); it was there he learned that his son had died. Shiva was held in the living room, where the actor Mandy Patinkin said Kaddish. 
 Soon thereafter, with Tony's medical equipment decommissioned, the Papps were able to return to Ninth Street. But in a way the Lear saga was far from over. Papp's real home had always been his theater, and that home had been falling into disarray since his diagnosis. As meticulously recounted by Helen Epstein in ''Joe Papp: An American Life,'' his increasing pain, his clandestine trips to Boston for treatment, his overall reluctance to deal with mortality had left the Public nearly rudderless while he made erratic stabs at designating a successor. That they would be erratic was almost a given: he was hoping to find in a single candidate the contradictory qualities he struggled his whole life to contain in himself. An aesthete but an entrepreneur. A dreamer but a doer. Joe Papp, the Shakespeare-spouting Manhattan sophisticate was also Joseph Papirofsky, the insecure son of Yiddish-speaking parents in Brooklyn. These precariously balanced extremes sometimes made him seem like a Saul Bellow character: scrappy, egotistical, nurturing, splenetic, charming, brutish, sentimental, blunt. He was too, too much -- which, in terms of inventing and sustaining the Public, was always just barely enough.
 According to Epstein, the first person he asked to replace him was Meryl Streep. (''I couldn't have been a more impractical choice,'' Streep said.) Then he approached a series of well-known directors: Mike Nichols, Jerry Zaks, James Lapine. They turned him down, some recognizing their limitations, some recognizing the Public's, all understanding the wisdom in the warning against following a star onstage. 
 so great was Papp's achievement, so disastrous his endgame, that 13 years after his death, the problem of how to follow him persists, even though two people have already done so. Last February, the second of them -- the Public's current producer, George C. Wolfe -- announced that he intends to step down soon after a successor is in place. The current search may lack the melodrama of the one that Papp undertook but is, in a way, more difficult. Pappian verve and vision, hard enough to find, must now be weighed against fiscal pressures and a cultural climate less hospitable to the Public's mission of new theatrical work at affordable prices. In England, where dashing artistic leaders are not yet extinct, you could start your list with Sam Mendes or Nicholas Hytner or Edward Hall. In America, though there are plenty of talented directors and a number of exciting and savvy producers, and even a few who are both, it's hard to think of a single figure who could make art, make news and make his way in the various nontheatrical venues (boardrooms, donors' salons, City Council chambers) that a successful artistic leader would also have to master.
 Unlike Papp, Wolfe has not been actively involved in the search for his successor, but he has told the board committee in charge of the process that the next artistic director must have an ''incredible sense of civic responsibility.'' A survey conducted by Albert Hall & Associates, the search firm hired by the Public, found the same thing: that the social mission of the theater is paramount. This puts the committee members, as they narrow the list (down as of this writing from 80 to ''a handful'') in a delicate position. Committed to honoring that mandate, they also know that the mandate is fragile and expensive; they must steer clear of potential candidates who are either unreasonably interesting (Tony Kushner, the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman) or uninterestingly reasonable. Most, if not all, of the finalists are white men who already run successful nonprofit theaters; some (like Oskar Eustis at Trinity Rep in Providence and Doug Hughes, who ran the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven for four years) are producer-directors, while others (like Jim Nicola of the New York Theater Workshop) are primarily producers. None are well known outside the theater, but then neither is Wolfe, even now. 
 Difficult though it is, the choice is at least being faced sensibly -- a decision is expected later this month -- whereas Papp wavered for years, finally settling on JoAnne Akalaitis, a founder of the avant-garde Mabou Mines company. Whatever her artistic skills or fitness for the job, there was very little likelihood of her succeeding, because immediately upon approaching her in 1989, Papp started to squirm, rejiggering the structure of the theater as if to humble the heir apparent. For a while, she and three other directors (Wolfe, Michael Greif and David Greenspan) were each given one of the Public's stages to program independently. With the kingdom divided so strangely, the playwright John Guare was moved to ask Wolfe which of Lear's daughters -- Goneril, Regan or Cordelia -- he was meant to be.
 Papp's maneuvering (which also included pitiful salary offers and a secret approach to another candidate) was designed, it now seems clear, to hamstring Akalaitis -- to prove that he was, in the end, irreplaceable. It worked: after Papp's death in October 1991, Akalaitis lasted 16 disastrous months in the job. On March 15, 1993, the board of the Public, thanking her for her service ''during this time of transition,'' fired her and hired Wolfe, who has led the theater ever since. And led it well. The record of his 11 years is one of both extraordinary artistic accomplishment and also fidelity to the theater's social vision. Yet Wolfe's achievement in those areas was not matched by equivalent success in stabilizing the finances and expanding the reach of the theater. Instead, the theater's operations have often been chaotic and the subscribers fickle. Which leads many to wonder whether the Public, even if it found another Papp or Wolfe, could afford him.
 And could such a person be persuaded to take on a very difficult job in a very vicious fishbowl? Some big names on the original list developed by Albert Hall have taken themselves off it. Prestige isn't what it used to be. The best directors today enjoy the freedom to work all over the world, to shuttle between commercial and nonprofit theaters, to set (or revise) their own artistic agendas instead of fulfilling someone else's. And producers may understandably be less impressed with the Public's opportunities than troubled by its limitations. ''Following an extremely charismatic and controversial artistic director into an institution that has five theaters to fill and a yearly operating budget of zero isn't my idea of a good time,'' said one of the 80 on the original list.
 He was exaggerating (the actual operating budget is $13 million), but there was a time when the country's greatest talents would be lining up for such a job regardless, when Thomas Hoving at the Metropolitan Museum, Rudolph Bing at the Metropolitan Opera, Beverly Sills at the New York City Opera, Harvey Lichtenstein at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Papp at the Public were stomping around New York nearly at once. Each had a big idea -- a new way of putting old things together -- and the charisma to sell it to audiences and donors. Lichtenstein's idea was to ennoble avant-garde art by transplanting it from cramped makeshift spaces into a vast gilded-age palace, where it could breathe; Papp did the opposite, making traditional art more democratic by taking it out of such palaces and into the park or a downtown black box, where it was cheap and accessible. One of his greatest innovations was touring Shakespeare throughout the city on a caravan of flatbed trucks.
 But the kind of personality that can make what is basically a programming initiative into a fervent political mission (or perhaps more accurately, can express a fervent political mission in terms of cultural programming) doesn't turn up much anymore. The cultural bigfoots -- the cover-of-Time types who either founded great institutions or became synonymous with their greatest flourishing -- have faded from view. Their successors are often less willing to give their whole lives to a cause; Wolfe wants to direct films and return to his writing. 
 A bigger reason for the extinction of the bigfoots is money. Many inspiring leaders, despite mesmerizing donors over cocktails, leave huge budgetary messes in their wake. Some of New York's great impresarios were more fiscally prudent than others, and some had lots more cash with which to be prudent, but even the poorer cousins, like Papp and Lichtenstein, tended to feed the vision first and the kitty later. ''Money follows art,'' Papp often said. Which is fine unless you're a supplier whose bill isn't being paid, or the bank holding the mortgage on your theater. 
 For Lichtenstein, as for almost all of the other nonprofit stars of his time, it was a matter of art for art's sake; when Ingmar Bergman became disenchanted with his company's production of ''The Misanthrope'' a month before it was to open at BAM in 1996, Lichtenstein simply canceled the sold-out run and refunded the tickets. For Papp, following the precepts of his Communist youth and the Group Theater he so admired, it was art for life's sake. He built his debt by supporting plays (and often, on formal or informal stipends, playwrights themselves) that spoke as directly as possible to his audience.
 For whomever's sake, art is expensive and (according to most artists) radically undersupported. This has only worsened in recent years. ''The bedrock of municipal and civic responsibility'' on which Papp (sometimes just hopefully) based his enterprise has largely eroded; the Public's annual grant from the National Endowment for the Arts was $40,000 in 2004. Given the difficult climate, search committees at some cultural institutions have begun to feel they may be better off with skilled managers instead of star impresarios. After Lichtenstein's retirement in 1999, BAM very successfully divided his job between two people you never hear about. Under Karen Brooks Hopkins, the president, and Joseph Melillo, the executive producer, who call themselves ''blue collar workers in the arts,'' the institution is financially -- and artistically -- sound. 
 Perhaps the mystery isn't so much where the bigfoots have gone as whether they're even wanted. If he were applying for the leadership of any large cultural institution today, let alone an inherently precarious one like the Public Theater, Joe Papp might not make it past the board interview. (''He would probably insult them all out of the room,'' Gersten says.) I'm not even sure that Wolfe, with his 1993 resume, could get the job now. When he was hired, he was only an artist. 
 So who could? Who should? 
The Public's answer largely depends on how much it feels it can afford to preserve the mission that Papp established. It's hard now to remember how transformative that mission once was. Papp, along with a few other nonprofit impresarios (Gordon Davidson at the Center Theater Group in Los Angeles and Zelda Fichandler at the Arena Stage in Baltimore) basically invented a form of American theater, based neither on Broadway nor in academia, that was rooted in civic life while embracing contemporary political concerns and nurturing new work. Beginning with his contention that Shakespeare needed rescuing from British blowhards and continuing through his championing of nonwhite and (to a lesser degree) female playwrights, Papp eventually built what Tony Kushner calls the flagship of socially conscious theater. ''People don't get the radicalism of Joe's mission,'' says Kushner, who has had several plays produced at the Public since 1991. ''There was an absolute commitment to a revolutionary relationship between life and art, and a mistrust of anything that compromised that.''
 But built into that mission was the mechanism of its perpetual undoing. The Public could never come close to balancing its budget without governmental aid. On the one hand, new work is rarely commercially successful, and Papp always insisted on allowing young writers to fail in hopes they would eventually succeed. (Many did: David Rabe, Wallace Shawn, Ed Bullins, Miguel Pinero, Ntozake Shange, John Guare, Elizabeth Swados, Thomas Babe, Dennis Reardon and John Ford Noonan were produced repeatedly at the Public.) On the other hand, in renovating the derelict Lafayette Street building to advance his vision, Papp built five intimate auditoriums -- none with more than 299 seats -- rather than one or two large ones. With all five selling cheap tickets (currently $50; subscribers pay less), and with the Public's largest venue, the 1,900-seat Delacorte in Central Park, free for anyone willing to wait in line, you have a structural mismatch of income and expenses. Alas, donors who might have closed the gap were not much tempted by violent prison dramas and feminist prose poems. Were it not for ''A Chorus Line,'' which opened at the Public in May 1975 before moving to Broadway two months later and running 15 years, it's questionable whether the theater would have survived at all. ''A Chorus Line'' brought almost $50 million into the Public's leaky coffers. 
 ''A Chorus Line,'' which was a daring musical, at least stylistically, in its time, turned a local institution devoted to noncommercial work into the most famous theater in the country and a freak of nature: a profitable nonprofit. With success came expansion: film series, Latino festivals, further adventures on Broadway and later in London. This, of course, meant setting up lines of authority to manage it all. There are people who can devise and live comfortably within the boxes imposed by ''good management,'' but Papp wasn't one of them. To the bitter end, he kept his kingdom chaotic and unbalanced; that was how he felt it ran best. He resisted all attempts to improve the Festival's finances at the expense of its mission by, for instance, charging small fees for Shakespeare in the Park even when it became hugely popular. As a result, by the time Akalaitis was appointed, the endowment built by ''A Chorus Line'' was down from $24 million to $13 million, most of the difference having gone to cover annual deficits that typically ran to $2.5 million. 
 While Akalaitis struggled to resolve the theater's contradictions, Wolfe, whose plays ''The Colored Museum'' and ''Spunk'' had been mounted to great acclaim under Papp, was emerging as the Public's star. There and in his Broadway productions of other people's work -- the musical ''Jelly's Last Jam'' and ''Angels in America'' in the early 90's -- he seemed effortlessly to do what Papp, as a director, never could: make high-flown ideas accessible in popular forms and raise lowbrow forms to a new level of expressiveness. 
 Directing shows that won prizes yet made money, Wolfe deftly leapt over the trap that the Public seemed fated to fall into. Gail Papp, who had worked at the theater since 1965 and was now on its board, began to think that Wolfe might be a godsend. True, he had no management experience. But he was young (37 at the time of her husband's death), quick and, as anyone who spent a minute with him knew, scarily energetic. As a gay black man, he believed in Papp's mission of inclusivity at least as deeply as Papp had himself; indeed, he seemed to embody it. 
''Growing up in a segregated town in Kentucky,'' Wolfe told me recently, ''there was this sense of responsibility, as part of the generation that integrated, to go in and be bright and charming and smart, and then to open up the door so other people could go in. For whatever reason -- I'm a forceful personality, I had ducked and dodged and people supported me -- I got my work done. But I know lots of artists who don't know how to duck and dodge, so I was feeling this sense of wanting to take care of them.''
 Sitting in his office at the Public, wearing striped jeans, a white T-shirt and sneakers, Wolfe -- who is turning 50 almost simultaneously with the theater -- looks like the skinny, owlish boy in the back of gym class who'd rather be reading. Even more than Papp, he inspires intense loyalty and frustration, sometimes from the same people. Unlike Akalaitis, who was called artistic director, Wolfe took Papp's title of producer and the wide swath of responsibility that went with it. And much as Papp had, he neglected to observe many niceties of institutional governance, like developing business plans for new ventures. ''I was on a huge learning curve,'' Wolfe admits.
 But the deeper criticism of Wolfe has little to do with his management style. It's the relationship between his role as the head of the institution and as an artist in his own right -- a problem that Papp and most of his bigfoot contemporaries rarely faced -- that has troubled some observers most. They say that Wolfe focused his energy and the theater's resources on his own work, leaving others to languish; that he foolishly pushed his own productions to Broadway and in so doing lost the institution a fortune; that he has hijacked Papp's great social vision as a vehicle for personal success -- in short, in answer to John Guare's question, that he's been the parricidal Regan and Goneril, rolled into one.
 It's true that not every production got the attention it merited or might have benefited from. But the rest of the rap isn't borne out by the record. The Broadway mountings of ''On the Town'' and ''The Wild Party'' (''My Two Big Flops,'' as Wolfe calls them) did lose the Public $11 million, but the nine other productions he moved uptown, directing six of them, brought about $9 million back. A $2 million loss over 11 years is not so bad, considering the worthiness of most of the transfers, which ranged in genre from a tap history of black life in America (''Bring in da Noise, Bring in da Funk'') to a one-woman lovefest (''Elaine Stritch at Liberty'') to this year's ''Caroline, or Change,'' which closed in August after a four-month run but was easily the best new serious musical on Broadway in years. (Under a new policy restricting investment in Broadway productions, the Public had only a minimal stake in the ''Caroline'' transfer, and thus lost little when it failed to thrive.) Papp often shed money on Broadway outings that were far less deserving.
 And if Wolfe expended a lot of energy on his own productions, that, he argues, is at least in part what he was hired to do. ''Being a working director was one of my huge drawing cards,'' he says. ''I was the whore in an Amsterdam window, saying, 'Woo woo woo, come on inside!''' Once lured there, theatergoers at the Public tended to get a good deal for their money -- not only in the work of playwrights Wolfe produced repeatedly (Suzan-Lori Parks, David Henry Hwang, Lisa Kron, Nilo Cruz, Diana Son) but also in the excitement of their interaction with classics and with each other. ''The goal was to make the lobby look like a subway stop,'' Wolfe says. ''I was intent on figuring out how much this institution on every single level -- the artists, the staff, the audience -- could reflect the city.''
 One of Wolfe's ideas for achieving that mix was Joe's Pub, a cabaret space established in 1998 in former administrative offices adjacent to the main building. Meant to introduce a new crowd to the Public and lure them to its regular offerings, the Pub was, at first, a financial disaster. And because the Pub has a separate entrance, there was virtually no cross-pollination with the theater. After a reorganization of the program -- scaled-back dining and two shows instead of one each night -- the Pub now turns a profit: $152,000 last year, enough to stage a small play. But the theater still gets letters saying he has diluted Papp's mission.
 That he has sometimes been criticized for pursuing the same policies that made Papp a hero -- new ventures aimed at young audiences, colorblind casting, loyalty to young black, gay and female playwrights -- suggests how seriously Wolfe has taken the mandate implicit in the name of his theater. Far from being a Regan or Goneril, Wolfe has been Papp's Cordelia, the child who most honored him, if on his own terms. 
Of course, there have been times during Wolfe's tenure when the Public resembled the kind of subway stop -- dim, deserted -- you don't want to enter. There have been endless crises and cutbacks. The institution, miraculously, found in Wolfe a cultural bigfoot to rank with the best of them, but it found him at a time when the environment for bigfoots was getting decidedly less congenial. The theater simply could not keep running at large deficits, no matter how valuable the work those deficits financed. The endowment was shriveling. Wolfe could not supervise the art going on in the theater or direct the shows that were its rainmakers while also schmoozing angels, managing the staff and courting foundations. If Papp had himself been ''too much,'' now the job was.
 And Wolfe was changing, too, which is one thing no one wants a bigfoot to do. His mother became ill in 1995 while he was rehearsing ''Bring in da Noise'' (during the day) and ''The Tempest'' (at night); in quick succession, she died, the shows opened, his house in Greenwich Village burned down and he was given a diagnosis of renal failure. Though he was able to keep working while on dialysis, his kidney transplant in 1997 brought most of his public activities to a halt. When they resumed, Wolfe and the board changed the leadership structure of the theater, making him for the first time co-equal with an executive director. In November 2000, Fran Reiter, a former deputy mayor for planning and economic development in the Giuliani administration, was given the position, with responsibility for the finances, marketing and development of the institution. 
 This was the structure that nearly every other major nonprofit theater in the country (and many other cultural organizations, like BAM) had settled on: what Bernard Gersten calls the ''twinsie'' arrangement. At Lincoln Center, Gersten himself is a twinsie, with the artistic director, Andre Bishop. At the Manhattan Theater Club, the artistic director, Lynne Meadow, and the executive director, Barry Grove, have been splitting (and sometimes blurring) the duties of running their institution since 1975. The value of this arrangement is obvious: the very different skills and energies needed for the job no longer have to be found in one person. (''I don't wanna be schlepping around Indonesia looking for a two-hour dance piece,'' says BAM's Hopkins.) The potential problem, beyond who's ultimately in charge, is subtler. The kind of person whose ego and charisma can keep an institution on the map is not often the kind who wants to share power with someone he most likely sees as a glorified accountant. 
 And yet the Roundabout Theater, which, almost uniquely, does not have a ''twinsie'' structure, is far more stable than the Public, with a subscriber base of 39,000 and a retention rate around 70 percent. (The Public has only about 6,000 subscribers and a rather alarming ''churn,'' with, until recently, fewer than half renewing each year.) The Roundabout is in fact run by an accountant, Todd Haimes, who has an M.B.A. from Yale and does not consider himself an artist. ''The advantage of my background is that all of my artistic decisions are being informed by management concerns,'' Haimes says. ''No one's ever going to accuse me of being a crazy artist. The disadvantage is the same: that perhaps there are brilliant things other people could accomplish that I just can't.''
 The Roundabout, like the Manhattan Theater Club and Lincoln Center Theater, has a different mission from the Public's. Gersten says it's enough of a mission for theaters like his just to survive. All three operate Broadway houses that sustain the more experimental and intimate work they do on their Off Broadway stages. But the Public is all experiment, all intimate. It does not program to attract huge audiences and couldn't sustain them if it did; there aren't enough seats. Beneath its leadership struggles there has always been the fear that a co-equal executive director would forget, or not care, that Papp had meant it to be that way, and would try to turn the Public into the Roundabout. 
 That fear proved to be grounded when Reiter took office. The official line is that she was phenomenally mismatched to Wolfe's personality, but in the wake of Sept. 11, which deepened the Public's perpetual fiscal crisis, it was much more serious than that. Through clenched teeth, Wolfe describes the problem as a matter of principles. ''This is an institution of new work, not of revivals, of daring work, not safe work, about taking on New York City and every aspect of it -- about what's next, new, chaotic. And when there becomes a thought process of fundamentally altering that, that is not correct for this institution.'' He purses his lips. ''Not to mention that this is a no-smoking building -- and the smoke pouring out of her office!'' 
 Reiter says that if she was mismatched to Wolfe's personality, she was the ''third or fourth in a long line'' of such mismatches. ''I don't believe George was accepting of anyone in that job doing what they were supposed to do,'' she told me. According to Reiter, she presented Kenneth B. Lerer, the chairman of the Public's board, with a he-goes-or-I-go ultimatum. Lerer chose Wolfe, Reiter left, two key board members resigned, the budget was slashed by 20 percent and the staff by 25 percent to avert disaster. Reiter's job remained empty for almost a year.
 No one inside the theater likes to admit, at least publicly, how bad things were. Good productions were mounted, but management was basically operating in permanent emergency mode. Required maintenance on the building was deferred, and the roof was literally about to fall in. (It would soon start raining in the theater.) When the board, after a formal search, hired Mara Manus as the new executive director, there were very few complaints (as there had been about Reiter) that she was not a theater person. She came to the Public from the Ford Foundation, where part of her job was to help midsize cultural nonprofits stay solvent and grow. But she had also spent 13 years as a Hollywood studio executive and, as such, was a realist about change. Soon after she arrived, Manus distributed to the board an excerpt from a book called ''Nonprofit Lifecycles.'' The handout described seven natural phases in the growth of such institutions: the Idea, the Start-Up, etc. 
 When I asked Manus which phase she thought the Public was in at the time, she said, ''Turnaround.'' 
 The only one after that was ''Terminal.''
Less than two years later, the Public was showing signs of renewed health. Income from ticket sales increased significantly, and last season was the first in eight years without an operating deficit. The roof is being fixed, and an $11 million capital-improvements program aimed at serving patrons (better seats and bathrooms, a more spacious lobby with direct access to Joe's Pub and a full-time cafe) is moving forward. Because individual gift-giving has also improved, the Delacorte, which had been forced to reduce its season to one play, is returning to a two-play schedule next summer. Perhaps most important, this all happened as the Public produced some of its best seasons in years. 
 Still, it has not been an easy transition. According to Manus, half the work force has turned over since she arrived. Staff members who reported directly to Wolfe (whether or not they could get his attention) may now report to Manus as well. These decisions have been mutual, and the two leaders work well together. (''She doesn't want my job, and I don't want hers,'' Wolfe says. ''She's not easily threatened. And she's not a bully.'') Still, some people who were let go, and some merely watching anxiously, fear the emergence of an un-Pappian emphasis on orderliness over creativity. But Manus doesn't think these are mutually exclusive. ''I would argue that an institution not in chaos provides greater opportunity for artists because the focus is then on creating a safe place to be unsafe,'' she says. ''That space is far more sacred when the chaos of the institutional instability does not invade it.''
 By splitting its leadership and finding an effective executive to fill the management half of the job, the Public has gone a long way toward solving its inborn structural problems. So why is there still such a yearning to fill the other half with a Papp redux? ''The person we need to hire has to be the equivalent of a star player for the New York Yankees,'' says Lerer, the Public's chairman. ''The moment that person's name is announced, their failures will be trumpeted and their triumphs will be destroyed. So it needs to be somebody who already knows how to operate on that stage.'' 
 But the desire for a bigfoot, it seems to me, is really the desire to preserve the Public's significance as a player in the life-or-death world of ideas. We want someone to bodily stop the culture's spotlight from passing irretrievably onto something trivial. When Lerer says that the next artistic director had better be someone you'd like to have dinner with (''Crazy people need not apply,'' he warns), it's a point well taken. But I'm not sure that anyone who isn't at least a little crazy can close his ears to the rest of the world and make the case -- and make it big -- that the kind of theater that made the Public the Public still matters.
