HEADLINE: The Next Green Revolution

BYLINE: By Pedro Sanchez. 
Pedro Sanchez, a 2004 MacArthur fellow, directs the Tropical Agriculture Program of the Earth Institute at Columbia University.

 BODY:
Africa is hungry and Americans would like to help. But we've been helping the wrong way -- by providing emergency food aid rather than enabling African farmers to produce more food. Last year the United States generously gave $500 million of emergency food aid to Ethiopia to help people survive the drought year. And how much did we provide to African farmers to help them be more productive over the long run? A small fraction of that amount -- $4 million.
 As a result of the Green Revolution in the 1960's, 70's and 80's, crop yields soared in India, China and Latin America, enabling them to break free of extreme hunger and recurrent famine. Indeed, these agricultural changes allowed countries like China and India to become the emerging markets they are today. 
 Tropical Africa -- which stretches from the southern edge of the Sahara to the Limpopo River on the border of South Africa -- is finally ready for its own Green Revolution. Crop yields there are miniscule, an average of 1,500 pounds of cereals per acre compared with 2,300 pounds in India and 4,900 pounds in China. 
 For better harvests, Africa's farmers need four things: nutrients for the soil, which can be provided by both mineral and organic fertilizers; small-scale irrigation and technologies for collecting rainwater; sturdier, higher-yield seeds; and a corps of master farmers, trained in up-to-date agricultural techniques, who could be posted in villages and would be able to provide advice. By introducing these measures, Africans could triple food production by 2015. 
 Unlike the Green Revolution of the 60's, an African Green Revolution doesn't have to be based on technologies and practices that hurt the environment. Land can be reclaimed not only through appropriate fertilization but through more environmentally sensitive techniques. For starters, there's agro-forestry, which involves planting trees that replenish the soil with nutrients like nitrogen. Farmers could also learn low-till or no-till farming techniques and be encouraged to plant pest-tolerant crops, which would cut down on insecticide and pesticide use. 
 What's more, small-scale irrigation projects like ones under way in northern Ethiopia can bring water to parched areas more effectively and economically than the large, expensive dam projects of old. Finally, after soil and water are taken care of, biotechnology can help, by fortifying African food crops against droughts and pests, and by increasing the nutritional content of staple foods. 
 A rise in crop yields would do more than end hunger. Raising the productivity of Africa's villages would also raise the status of the women on the continent. Women do much of the farming in Africa today, growing 80 percent of the food there -- and they work mostly without tools or modern technologies. If farming was easier, women would be freer to find work off the farm, more girls would be able to stay in school and children would have better food to eat. History has shown that women's empowerment in turn leads to lower population growth and to advances in children's health and education. In addition, using locally grown foods in feeding programs for infants and children will generate additional demand, helping African agriculture to strengthen itself.
 Given the possible rewards of African renewal, the price tag is small. Key investments on the order of $50 per person per year in tropical African villages would put the continent on the path to long-term sustainable development. Additional annual aid from the developed world might therefore be around $25 billion, a small fraction of what we spend over the long run on emergency food aid, disease epidemics and fighting terrorism and violence in failed states. 
 If we take these simple steps -- and promote good governance in African countries -- the continent has the potential to go from basket case to trading partner. A sign I saw at a Florida bait shop says it all: ''Give people a fish and they will eat for a day; teach people how to fish and they will eat for their lifetime and they will buy fishing equipment.''

HEADLINE: Oil Prices and Growth Data Drag Share Prices Down

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks closed mostly lower yesterday as record oil prices and economic data showing slower-than-expected growth last month weighed on the markets.
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 38.86 points, or 0.38 percent, at 10,177.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended down 0.69 point, or 0.06 percent, at 1,134.48. The Nasdaq composite index closed up 3.10 points, or 0.16 percent, at 1,955.50. 
 The American International Group, the world's largest insurer by market value, dragged on the Dow and the S.&P. 500. A.I.G. is facing a possible lawsuit by United States securities regulators over actions and statements it made related to a major banking client. A.I.G. shares fell 3 percent, to $66.50.
 Crude oil ended above $51 a barrel for the first time as production in the Gulf of Mexico recovered slowly after Hurricane Ivan hit the region three weeks ago. Energy stocks, including Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips and ChevronTexaco, were among the gainers in the S.&P. 500.
 Exxon Mobil rose 40 cents, or almost 1 percent, to $49.32, while ConocoPhillips closed at a 52-week high, with its shares up $2.03, or 2.4 percent, to $86.70. ChevronTexaco hit a 52-week high during the session, but eased somewhat to close with a gain of 59 cents, or 1.1 percent, at $54.45.
 Earlier, data on the services sector showed that growth slowed last month. The Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing survey for September showed its index of activity slipped to 56.7. Economists had expected the index to rise to 59 from 58.2 in the previous month.
 A number above 50 indicates growth, while a figure below that denotes contraction in the sector, which accounts for about 80 percent of the United States economy.
 On the employment front, a report from Challenger, Gray & Christmas said planned job cuts soared to an eight-month high in September while new hiring rose only slightly.
 Chiron, which makes half the flu vaccine used in the United States, fell 16 percent, to $37.98 as the company said it would not supply any vaccine for the coming flu season because of problems at its plant in Britain.
 Medimmune, which makes a flu vaccine called FluMist nasal spray, rose 5.8 percent, to $25.78, helping the Nasdaq. 
 Companies including the heavy equipment maker Caterpillar, the aerospace company United Technologies and the diversified manufacturer 3M, which are sensitive to swings in the economy, weighed on the Dow.
 Caterpillar fell 1 percent, or 88 cents, to $80.37; United Technologies closed down 79 cents, or 0.8 percent, at $93.76; and 3M slipped 18 cents, or 0.2 percent, to $78.76.
 Pulte Homes, the home builder, fell nearly 7 percent, to $52.45, after the company issued an earnings warning Monday, citing softness in the once-booming Las Vegas housing market.
 Ruby Tuesday, the restaurant chain, fell about 15 percent, to $23.35, a day after it trimmed its outlook for 2005. 
 Prices of Treasury securities were nearly steady yesterday, despite the weaker-than-expected report on the services sector and record crude oil prices. Dealers were wary ahead of Friday's September payrolls report. By late in the day, the price of the benchmark 10-year note fell 3/32, to 100 19/32. The yield was at 4.17 percent, unchanged from Monday.

HEADLINE: Near Las Vegas, but a World Apart

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
Summerlin, a vast community built from scratch on arid land, may be only about 10 miles to the west of this city's Strip but it is a world apart from that flashy playground, with its anything-goes aesthetic.
 In Summerlin, strict controls abound: streetlamps direct light downward to reduce the glare, the signs are unobtrusive, the concrete used to build the big-box stores is engineered to look like sandstone, and houses must be painted in colors that harmonize with the desert landscape.
 Rules like these have helped to make Summerlin one of the best-selling planned communities in the nation. Thirteen years after the first residents moved in, Summerlin is already home to more than 87,000 people. It is on 22,500 acres bought in 1952 by Howard Hughes, the eccentric movie producer and aircraft manufacturer and designer, who died in 1976. 
 The community, named for Mr. Hughes's paternal grandmother, Jean Amelia Summerlin, is operated by a company formed by his heirs. The Howard Hughes Corporation has built Summerlin's roads and parks and some of the commercial buildings, but it sells housing lots to other developers. Another 6,600 acres are left.
 What distinguishes Summerlin from many other planned communities is the high quality of its public buildings and its extensive trail system, now stretching 107 miles, said Richard E. Heapes, a founding partner of Street-Works, a development and consulting company in Alexandria, Va. ''There has been a genuine attempt through the trails system to knit the community together,'' said Mr. Heapes, who served on a jury of a nonprofit real estate industry group, the Urban Land Institute, that gave Summerlin an award in 2002.
 Since 1996, Hughes has been a division of the Rouse Company of Columbia, Md., a pioneer in both the shopping mall and land development industries. But in August, Rouse agreed to be acquired by General Growth Properties, a giant mall owner based in Chicago, for $7.2 billion in cash and $5.4 billion in assumed debt. General Growth has not said whether it plans to get out of the land business, although several analysts said a sale was unlikely. Officials at both Rouse and General Growth declined to comment.
 The deal, which is expected to be approved by Rouse shareholders before the end of the year, has been roundly criticized by most Wall Street analysts because of its rich price and the mountain of debt that General Growth is taking on. Fitch Ratings and Moody's Investors Service served notice that they were considering downgrading Rouse and General Growth bonds.
 Summerlin and Rouse's six other community developments were a driving force behind the company's decision to seek a buyer, Rouse said last month in a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. As a real estate investment trust, Rouse is not subject to corporate income tax but is allowed to have a taxable subsidiary. But the value of the taxable portion of its land business -- including Columbia, Md., and a 52.5 percent interest in the Woodlands, outside Houston -- may not exceed 20 percent of the value of all of its assets.
 With mall prices rapidly rising, Rouse apparently believed it could no longer justify buying more shopping centers to offset the gains from its land assets, said Matthew Ostrower, a retail REIT analyst at Morgan Stanley.
 Selling the land development business separately would have created a huge tax liability, Rouse said. And under its agreement with the Hughes heirs, the company said, Summerlin cannot be sold until 2009.
 Mr. Ostrower and other analysts cited other reasons that led to Rouse's decision to sell: the high prices that malls are currently commanding and the huge sums that top executives stand to receive. David M. Fick, a managing director at Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore, estimated that Anthony W. Deering, the 59-year-old chairman of Rouse, would get more than $110 million.
 The proxy statement also illustrates the feverish competition for mall properties as huge REIT's try to expand their business when there are few desirable locations left for large shopping centers. General Growth did not initiate the merger discussions, but it took the company only six weeks to reach a decision after it was invited to bid on Rouse, a time frame that other potential buyers said was too compressed.
 According to the proxy statement, another REIT -- believed to be the Simon Property Group -- approached Rouse first, at an industry conference in June, but later complained that it was not given enough time to evaluate the prospective deal.
 Negotiations with a third REIT, the Westfield Group, went further, but Westfield was unwilling to acquire Rouse's land development interests. 
 (Simon and Westfield officials would not confirm that the proxy statement referred to their companies.)
 With this merger, General Growth will have debt equal to more than 70 percent of its total capitalization, far more than the current average leverage for shopping malls of 48.5 percent, Mr. Ostrower said.
 Paul Morgan of Friedman, Billings, Ramsey, one of the few retail REIT analysts who has welcomed the merger, said that General Growth would own 22 of the top malls in the country, giving it more influence with the most prestigious retailers. The company will also become the dominant mall owner in Las Vegas, with five properties, including Rouse's Fashion Show Mall on the Strip.
 William Travers, a director at Fitch, said that General Growth was weighing several options that might include a combination of refinancing existing mortgages, placing new mortgages on unencumbered property, selling Rouse's nine-million-square-foot office buildings, or issuing new stock. Although the land business is new to General Growth, Greg Andrews, a retail REIT analyst at Green Street Advisors, said he did not expect the company to sell the land business. ''From the indications they have given, the more they learn about it, the more they like it,'' he said. 
 For Summerlin, the proposed change in ownership is coming just as work is beginning on a 400-acre hub that will include prime office space, a regional shopping center and urban-style residential units. Tom Warden, a Hughes vice president, said that ''an urban village is a solution to a lot of problems'' that the Las Vegas Valley -- the fastest-growing metropolitan area in the nation during the 1990's -- is facing. These days, it can take as long as an hour to drive to downtown Las Vegas from Summerlin, water conservation is a major concern and land prices have been skyrocketing.
 In May 2001, for example, the Bureau of Land Management, which controls 85 percent of the land in Nevada, sold 1,900 acres for $25,000 an acre to American Nevada and the Del Webb Corporation, the developers of the Aliante community in North Las Vegas. Last June, the Focus Property Group paid $287,000 an acre for a 1,940-acre parcel in Henderson.
 With many executives living in or near Summerlin, there is likely to be demand for high-grade office space, provided that land costs do not make rents prohibitive, said Michael R. Dunn, a director at Cushman & Wakefield. He estimated that annual rents would have to be at least $31 a square foot -- a level seen only at the Howard Hughes Center, a 1.1-million-square-foot office complex east of the Strip.
 The rising cost of land is making it inevitable that building heights will rise, a source of concern to residents. Last year, they forced Station Casinos to reduce the scale of the Red Rock Station, a 400-room hotel and 87,000-square-foot casino that is scheduled to open in Summerlin Centre in 2006. The company originally sought to build a 300-foot tower but settled for 198 feet, or 17 stories.
 Under the master plan, two 19-story office buildings could be built in Summerlin Centre, but the first complex will be of more modest scale. Business Bank of Nevada plans to break ground early next year on two three-story buildings with 150,000 square feet of prime space and expects to lease all but 40,000 square feet, said Paul Stowell, a senior vice president.
 Gabriel Lither, the president of Summerlin Residents for Responsible Growth, said that most homeowners realized that more density was coming. ''We don't have the land or the water to keep having sprawl,'' he said. 
 He also said the height of a building should not be dictated solely by plans that were made years ago. ''Our concern is that one area might be overbuilt, with buildings that are too dense -- too tall,'' he said. ''They have the right to do it, but they should do it with community support.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Board Is Said Not to Vote On Chief's Plan for Lazard
The board of Lazard met in Paris but did not vote on a plan by its chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein, to take the firm public, two people close to the company said. Not all of the firm's working partners, who own 64 percent of the company, have signed off on the plan, they said.
 If Lazard decides to go ahead with an offering, the directors would have to approve the plan. But no board meeting is currently scheduled for that purpose, one of these people said. [Page C2.]

Google Disproves Its Doubters
Shares of Google, the Internet search engine, broke the $135 ceiling, closing at $138.37. In August, when Google shares started trading at $85 a share, there was no shortage of naysayers eager to caution the average investor against paying a high premium for what they considered a risky stock. [C4.]

Flu Vaccine to Be in Short Supply
The Chiron Corporation said it would be unable to supply any of the 46 million to 48 million doses of flu vaccine it had planned to sell in the United States this year -- nearly half the expected supply -- because its manufacturing license had been suspended at a British factory where the vaccine is made. [A1.]

Houses Passes Bill on Military Sales
The House of Representatives approved a measure aimed at preventing marketing practices that have exposed military personnel to high-pressure or misleading sales pitches for financial products. [C6.]

US Airways Pilots Will Vote on Cuts
The leaders of the pilots' union at US Airways have agreed to send the latest concessions to a vote of the members. [C4.]

F.C.C. Is Assailed on Funding
The Federal Communications Commission came under sharp criticism in Congress over decisions that have led to the suspension of a $2.25 billion program that pays for telephone and Internet services at the nation's public schools and libraries. [C4.]

Ink Expert Is Acquitted
Larry F. Stewart, the Secret Service ink expert who was accused of lying on the stand in the obstruction of justice trial of Martha Stewart, was acquitted of two charges of perjury. Mr. Stewart, who is no relation to Ms. Stewart, was charged with lying in his testimony about his role in analyzing notations made with blue pen on a document listing Ms. Stewart's stock holdings. [C2.]

September Services Index Falls
An index of services in the United States dropped to a 16-month low in September and suggested that high energy prices may limit the economic expansion. [C3.]

Crude Oil Prices Top $51 a Barrel
Oil prices in New York climbed above $51 a barrel as traders focused on supplies from the Gulf of Mexico, where production is still suffering delays after Hurricane Ivan. [C8.]

Stocks closed mostly lower as oil prices rose. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 38.86 points, at 10,177.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended down 0.69 point, at 1,134.48. The Nasdaq composite index closed up 3.10 points, at 1,955.50. [C8.]

HEADLINE: Country Music in the City? 2005 Nashville Awards Go to New York

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE; Phil Sweetland contributed reporting from Nashville for this article.

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who donned a tan cowboy hat, joked that he was working on a song called ''Mamas, Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Mayors.''
 Trace Adkins, in a black cowboy hat, called the mayor ''a country music wannabe.''
 Such was the repartee at City Hall yesterday, as the mayor and Country Music Association officials announced that the annual country music awards show, held in Nashville for more than 30 years, was going to Madison Square Garden next year for the first time.
 It was a festive news conference, laced with the seeming incongruity of the city of Broadway shows holding country music's biggest awards program. But Mr. Bloomberg said the Nov. 15, 2005, show from New York, to be broadcast as usual on CBS, will give the city an economic boost of as much as $30 million and show off its post-9/11 glory. 
 For country music fans, it is a chance for their art to shine in the nation's media capital and perhaps lure new fans and new viewers, said Kix Brooks, president of the C.M.A.'s board of directors and half of the recording duo Brooks & Dunn, which performed at the Republican convention last month.
 ''New York City has a proven track record of hosting the biggest and most watched events around the globe,'' Mr. Bloomberg said, ''including the 2002 N.F.L. Kickoff in Times Square, the 2003 Grammy Awards and most recently the 2004 Republican National Convention.'' 
 Yesterday a reporter asked Mr. Bloomberg if the cowboy hat would become a permanent part of his wardrobe. And the Nashville visitors presented him with a shiny brown guitar.
 More seriously, Mr. Brooks stressed that the C.M.A. had no plans to abandon Nashville, where the 38th annual awards program will be broadcast on Nov. 9 from its traditional home at the Grand Ole Opry. Rather, he said, this was a one-time deal to bring a bit of country to New York, with exhibitions and concerts planned in the week before the 2005 awards show.
 Unlike most other players of popular music, country musicians have often been strongly identified with one city, Nashville. New York City does not even have a radio station solely for country. 
 But the city and the music are not such an odd mix, other officials from the C.M.A. suggested. When Garth Brooks performed in Central Park in 1997, the concert drew the largest audience in the park's history, they said. They noted that nearly 2.5 percent of country music was sold in New York City, and that artists like the Dixie Chicks, Willie Nelson and Shania Twain depend on the city for up to 11 percent of their album sales.
 The country music awards show is already one of the most popular events on television, and a New York location just lends more excitement and glamour, Jack Sussman, CBS vice president for specials, said at the news conference. He said that last year the show was watched by more than 40 million people, roughly half the television audience of the Academy Awards and slightly more than the number of people who tuned in to the Emmy Awards.
 Mr. Adkins, who is on the C.M.A. board of directors, drew laughter when he said, ''We know there are a lot of country music fans in New York City and at least one country music wannabe,'' referring to Mr. Bloomberg.
 At the beginning of the news conference, Mr. Bloomberg was shown strumming a guitar and singing (in a voice made for print) in a short film used to court C.M.A. officials. He hailed the awards show as a coup on the part of a city office called NYC Big Events, which tries to bring high-profile shows and contests to the city. 
 ''If we do a great job, they'll be back,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. 
 In Nashville reaction was mixed to the news. Some saw it as a potential boon for country music sales, while others complained that New York had few real ties to country.
 ''It will be very positive for country music,'' said Lou Helton, the Nashville bureau chief of the trade newspaper Radio & Records. ''New York is the world's biggest stage, with more media than any other city in the world. Packing 17,000-plus into Madison Square Garden will also demonstrate the widespread popularity of 'America's Music.'''
 But Hazel Smith, a veteran music journalist and a regular on ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show,'' groused: ''Bloomberg wants the dollars for New York City. Since 9/11, he's striven to rake in the bucks any way he can. His Honor cares nothing about and knows nothing about country music or country singers.''
 ''There's not even a country radio station in New York,'' Ms. Smith said. ''Now if the Emmys will agree to come to Music Town See. Makes no sense, does it?'' 
 Mr. Bloomberg, in answer to a question about the aggressive marketing of the city, said these were competitive times for tourism and events. No big city in the world is not advertising itself, he added. New York's diversity, openness and concentration of media make it ''the place to go,'' Mr. Bloomberg said.

HEADLINE: For Cheney and Edwards, a Night of Sharp Exchanges

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
In a strikingly personal and bitter debate, Vice President Dick Cheney defended the Bush administration's record on Iraq on Tuesday night as ''exactly the right thing to do'' and asserted that Senators John Kerry and John Edwards bent with the political winds on national security.
 Mr. Edwards fired back with a wide-ranging assault on the administration's honesty and competence in foreign and domestic policy. ''One thing that's very clear is that a long resume does not equal good judgment,'' Mr. Edwards declared, in one of many sharp exchanges that spoke to the closeness of the race and the differences between the two tickets.
 Mr. Cheney was defiantly unapologetic about the course of the conflict in Iraq, defending the administration against the charge that it had failed to provide enough troops to stabilize Iraq, as the former top American official in Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, said in a speech on Monday. [Page A22.] 
 Mr. Cheney said he would recommend the same course in Iraq if he had it to do over again, adding, ''The world is safer today because Saddam Hussein is in jail, his government's no longer in power, and we did exactly the right thing.'' [Excerpts, Page A24; video, nytimes.com.]
 Mr. Edwards shot back, ''Mr. Vice President, you are still not being straight with the American people.'' He repeatedly charged that Mr. Cheney had conflated the threat from Mr. Hussein with Al Qaeda, and argued that the United States needed a ''fresh start'' and new leadership if it was to succeed in Iraq.
 The bitter tone of the debate, held at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, extended across a range of issues, from Mr. Cheney's tenure as chief executive of Halliburton to Mr. Edwards's voting record. 
 Mr. Edwards appeared to hold his own in the remarkably intense thrust and parry of the evening, at times putting Mr. Cheney on the defensive. But their confrontation contained nothing that is likely to alter the race fundamentally, and the focus is likely to shift rapidly back to the top of their respective tickets. Mr. Bush is giving a speech on terrorism and the economy on Wednesday morning, and he and Mr. Kerry will debate each other two more times, on Friday in St. Louis and next Wednesday in Tempe, Ariz.
 After what many viewed as a lackluster performance by Mr. Bush in last week's debate, Mr. Cheney returned to the harsh attacks of the Republican convention, asserting that Mr. Kerry was unprincipled on national security and could not be trusted to be as aggressive as the Republicans in protecting the nation. 
 He asserted that the Kerry-Edwards ticket had shifted positions to suit its political needs. ''Now, if they couldn't stand up to the pressures that Howard Dean represented, how can we expect them to stand up to Al Qaeda?''' Mr. Cheney asked.
 Five days after Mr. Bush's first encounter with Mr. Kerry, in Florida last Thursday, Mr. Cheney was under pressure to halt any momentum the Democratic ticket had picked up and sharpen the Republican assault on Mr. Kerry. After weeks in which Mr. Bush held a steady lead, polls have shown the race tightening markedly, to a statistical dead heat in several of them.
 For Mr. Edwards, the 90-minute debate, moderated by Gwen Ifill of PBS, was a major political test, pitting him against a far more experienced opponent.
 With so much at stake, both men unleashed their sharpest attacks, each describing his opponent -- seated just inches away -- with withering contempt. Referring to Halliburton, Mr. Edwards said, ''The facts are, the vice president's company, that he was C.E.O. of, that did business with sworn enemies of the United States, paid millions of dollars in fines for providing false financial information.'' That company, Mr. Edwards added, ended up with a $7.5 billion no-bid contract for work in Iraq.
 Mr. Cheney shot back that the Democrat was raising Halliburton as a smokescreen to obscure his own record in the Senate, which was, he asserted, ''not very distinguished' and marked by so many missed votes that a local newspaper called him Senator Gone. The vice president added that he was presiding officer of the Senate, yet, ''The first time I ever met you was when you walked onto the stage tonight.''
 Mr. Edwards's spokesman, Mark Kornblau, said later that Mr. Edwards had met Mr. Cheney twice previously, at the National Prayer Breakfast on Feb. 1, 2001, and at the swearing in of Senator Elizabeth Dole, Republican of North Carolina.
 Mr. Edwards, his sunny smile gone cold, replied that Mr. Cheney's voting record included voting against such popular programs and initiatives as Head Start, the creation of the Department of Education, meals on wheels for the elderly, and a federal holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. 
 One of the rare moments of personal warmth Tuesday night came on the issue of gay marriage. Mr. Cheney, who has a gay daughter, reiterated his support for the idea that marriage should be regulated by the states, in contrast to Mr. Bush's call for a federal constitutional ban on same-sex marriage. ''People ought to be free to choose any arrangement they want,'' he said. ''It's really no one else's business.'' Mr. Edwards praised Mr. Cheney for openly embracing his daughter.
 When Ms. Ifill turned the discussion to domestic policy, Mr. Edwards jumped in with gusto, noting that under Mr. Bush the economy has so far suffered a net loss of jobs, putting him at risk of becoming the first president in 70 years not to post a record of employment gains.
 From the first moments of the debate, Mr. Cheney and Mr. Edwards clashed sharply and directly on Iraq. Mr. Cheney, pressing the party's attacks of recent days, asserted that Mr. Kerry had embraced a ''global test'' for the pre-emptive use of force in last week's debate.
 Mr. Cheney described it as a ''part of a track record that goes back to the 1970's'' of being ''on the wrong side of defense issues,'' and said the Democrats gave no indication of being willing to go forward aggressively in the war on terror.
 Mr. Edwards countered, ''What John Kerry said, and it's just as clear as day to anybody who was listening, He said, 'We will find terrorists where they are and kill them before they ever do harm to the American people.'''
 Mr. Edwards pointed out that Mr. Kerry had explicitly said he would never give any other nation a veto over American national security decisions. But he said the American people and the rest of the world deserved to know the full truth about why the United States was going to war. 
 ''It is critical that we be credible,'' Mr. Edwards said. ''They need to know that the credibility of the United States is always good.''
 The two candidates met around a table, a format favored by Mr. Cheney's team because they said it would play to what they characterized as the vice president's strengths: his low-key but earnest manner. The atmosphere from the start was chilly. The two men came out on stage, shook hands and then immediately sat down and began taking notes on yellow legal pads, exchanging barely a glance.
 The personal contrast between the two vice presidential candidates could not have been more striking. At 51, Mr. Edwards was participating in his first one-on-one televised debate, a measure of his meteoric six-year rise in electoral politics, from millionaire trial lawyer to first-term senator from North Carolina to the No. 2 spot on the Democratic ticket. 
 Even so, Republicans asserted that his skills as a courtroom lawyer steeped in the Southern populist tradition made him a formidable opponent. Before the debate, Matthew Dowd, President Bush's campaign strategist and an expert in the art of lowering political expectations for his team, called Mr. Edwards a ''cross between Atticus Finch and William Jennings Bryan.''
 Mr. Cheney's job was made all the more difficult by a confluence of events, including the continued violence in Iraq, that raised questions about his advocacy of the invasion of Iraq and the administration's planning for what came after Saddam Hussein was deposed.
 In a speech on Monday, Mr. Bremer, who oversaw the American presence in Iraq until the handover of sovereignty early this summer, said the United States had failed to put enough troops on the ground to assure security in Iraq. Mr. Kerry seized on Mr. Bremer's comments to buttress his case that Mr. Bush had mishandled the war, a line of argument Mr. Edwards pressed.
 Mr. Cheney said that Iraq had been an appropriate target after the Sept. 11 attacks because of its ''established relationship with Al Qaeda'' and that Iraq had been the ''nexus'' that could provide terrorists with access to nuclear, biological or chemical weapons.
 But Mr. Edwards, in his first response, challenged Mr. Cheney's credibility. He said that Mr. Cheney and Mr. Bush "continue to tell people things are going well in Iraq,'' an assertion he said was obviously false to the American people who can see otherwise everyday on television.
 Mr. Edwards also accused Mr. Cheney of falsely linking the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001 and Iraq. ''There is no connection between attacks of 9/11 and Saddam Hussein,'' he said. ''You said there is some connection; there is not.''
 When Ms. Ifill asked if a Kerry-Edwards administration would have acted differently when confronted with the threat of Saddam Hussein, Mr. Edwards said that Mr. Hussein ''needed to be confronted'' but that United Nations weapons inspectors should have been given more time. He said the American invasion of March 2003 had distracted attention fom Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden, who were responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks.
 ''We had Osama bin Laden cornered at Tora Bora,'' he said. "We had the finest military in the world on the ground.'' Asked whether the administration moved too quickly to leave the fight in Afghanistan, Mr. Cheney said the administration had "never let up on Osama bin Laden from Day One. We'll continue to aggressively pursue him and I'm confident we'll get him.'' The Vice President said that Mr. Edwards did not appreciate or understand the progress that had taken place in Afghanistan and he criticized him for saying two years ago that the country was in chaos.

HEADLINE: Warming to Brazil, Powell Says Its Nuclear Program Isn't a Concern

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, stepping up the American courtship of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, said Tuesday that the United States had no concerns that Brazil was planning to develop nuclear weapons despite the country's resistance to allowing international inspectors greater access to one of its nuclear reactors.
 After meeting with President da Silva and other Brazilian leaders, Mr. Powell also offered another gesture to Brazilian aspirations, saying that Brazil's contributions to peacekeeping in Haiti and other actions made it was worthy of consideration for permanent membership on the United Nations Security Council. 
 The United Nations is studying the possibility of increasing the number of permanent seats in response to demands for membership from several countries, including India, Brazil, Germany and Japan. At present, only the United States, Britain, France, China and Russia are permanent members, which carries the right to veto any resolution.
 Mr. Powell was noncommittal as to whether the United States would endorse Brazil's addition, saying that Washington was awaiting results of a study by a panel appointed by Secretary General Kofi Annan. But he did say that Brazil would be a strong candidate.
 On the nuclear issue, Mr. Powell addressed a question about concerns in many countries that Brazil's opposition to unlimited inspections, as sought by the International Atomic Energy Agency, might embolden other nations like Iran and North Korea to reject inspections of their suspected nuclear arms programs.
 ''I don't have those concerns,'' Mr. Powell said at a news conference after meeting with Foreign Minister Celso Amorim. ''I don't think Brazil can be talked about in the same vein or put in the same category as Iran or North Korea.''
 He said that Iran and North Korea, for example, had either expelled international inspectors or refused to cooperate with them in disclosing nuclear facilities, and that many experts agreed that those countries were making nuclear weapons. North Korea, he noted, has announced its nuclear arms program as a matter of policy.
 ''The United States understands that Brazil has no interest in a nuclear weapon, no desire and no plans, no programs, no intention of moving toward a nuclear weapon,'' Mr. Powell said in an interview on TV Globo. ''They have a nuclear power program. We understand that.''
 In a speech to business leaders, talks with President da Silva and in interviews with local news media, Mr. Powell used his day-and-a-half visit to push the idea that Brazil was emerging as a dominant power in the region and one that the United States -- perhaps to its surprise -- could do business with on a number of fronts.
 Since his election in 2002 as the first president from the leftist Workers Party, Mr. da Silva has been cultivated by the Bush administration in the hope that he would soften his economic policies and serve as a moderating influence in Latin America, despite his alliance with such leftist leaders as Fidel Castro of Cuba and Hugo Chavez of Venezuela.
 American officials say that strategy has worked, and that under Mr. da Silva Brazil has hewed to a pro-capitalist, pro-investment and fiscally conservative line. This year, Mr. da Silva sent Brazilian forces as peacekeepers to Haiti under the aegis of the United Nations to keep order after the forced resignation of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
 Foreign Minister Amorim said that he expected the dispute with the International Atomic Energy Agency over inspectors' access to Brazil's enriched-uranium facilities would be resolved soon by technical experts.
